title: Artificial Intelligence Accountability and Transparency Act of 2024
text:
To establish standards for the development, deployment, and oversight of artificial intelligence systems used by Federal agencies and Government contractors, and for other purposes.

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. This Act may be cited as the 'Artificial Intelligence Accountability and Transparency Act of 2024'.

SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. In this Act: (1) ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE SYSTEM. The term 'artificial intelligence system' means any computational system that uses machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, or other techniques derived from the field of artificial intelligence to perform tasks that would otherwise require human cognition, including but not limited to classification, prediction, recommendation, or decision-making. (2) COVERED AGENCY. The term 'covered agency' means any Executive agency as defined in section 105 of title 5, United States Code. (3) HIGH-RISK AI APPLICATION. The term 'high-risk AI application' means any artificial intelligence system that is used to make or materially support decisions affecting the rights, safety, or access to critical resources of individuals, including but not limited to employment screening, credit determinations, criminal risk assessment, and eligibility for Government benefits.

SEC. 3. ALGORITHMIC IMPACT ASSESSMENTS. (a) IN GENERAL. Each covered agency shall, before deploying any high-risk AI application, complete an algorithmic impact assessment that evaluates the system's accuracy, fairness, bias, and potential for discriminatory outcomes across demographic groups defined by race, gender, age, disability status, and national origin. (b) PUBLIC DISCLOSURE. Each covered agency shall publish a summary of each algorithmic impact assessment on the agency's public website not later than 30 days after completion of the assessment.

title: Rural Broadband Infrastructure Expansion Act
text:
To amend the Communications Act of 1934 to provide for the expansion of broadband infrastructure in underserved rural communities, and for other purposes.

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. This Act may be cited as the 'Rural Broadband Infrastructure Expansion Act'.

SEC. 2. FINDINGS. Congress finds the following: (1) Approximately 21 million Americans, predominantly in rural areas, lack access to broadband internet service meeting the Federal Communications Commission's benchmark speed of 100 megabits per second download and 20 megabits per second upload. (2) The lack of adequate broadband infrastructure in rural communities creates significant disparities in access to telehealth services, remote education, precision agriculture technologies, and economic opportunities. (3) Federal investment in broadband infrastructure is necessary to close the digital divide and ensure that all Americans can participate fully in the modern economy.

SEC. 3. RURAL BROADBAND GRANT PROGRAM. (a) ESTABLISHMENT. The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information shall establish a competitive grant program to fund the deployment of broadband infrastructure in eligible rural areas. (b) ELIGIBLE ENTITIES. The following entities are eligible to receive grants under this section: (1) Local governments and tribal authorities. (2) Electric cooperatives and other nonprofit entities. (3) Internet service providers committing to offer service at speeds meeting or exceeding the FCC benchmark for not less than 10 years following the completion of funded infrastructure. (c) AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. There is authorized to be appropriated $12,000,000,000 for fiscal years 2025 through 2030 to carry out this section.

title: Prescription Drug Pricing Fairness Act
text:
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide for negotiation of prices of certain drugs and biologicals covered under Medicare part B, and for other purposes.

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. This Act may be cited as the 'Prescription Drug Pricing Fairness Act'.

SEC. 2. NEGOTIATION OF PRICES FOR CERTAIN DRUGS AND BIOLOGICALS UNDER MEDICARE PART B. (a) IN GENERAL. Section 1847A of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395w-3a) is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection: (i) NEGOTIATION OF MAXIMUM FAIR PRICES. (1) IN GENERAL. With respect to a negotiation-eligible drug (as defined in paragraph (2)), the Secretary shall negotiate with the manufacturer of such drug to determine a maximum fair price that shall apply to the drug under this section. (2) NEGOTIATION-ELIGIBLE DRUG DEFINED. The term 'negotiation-eligible drug' means a drug or biological covered under this part that (A) has been approved or licensed for marketing for not less than 7 years as of the date of the negotiation, (B) is not a generic drug or biosimilar product, and (C) accounts for expenditures under this part in excess of $200,000,000 during the preceding 12-month period.

SEC. 3. INFLATION REBATES. If the average sales price of a drug or biological covered under Medicare part B increases during any calendar quarter at a rate that exceeds the rate of inflation as measured by the consumer price index for all urban consumers, the manufacturer of such drug shall pay a rebate to the Secretary in an amount equal to the difference between the actual average sales price and the inflation-adjusted price multiplied by the total number of units sold under Medicare part B during such quarter.

title: National Cybersecurity Workforce Development Act of 2024
text:
To establish a national strategy for developing the cybersecurity workforce, to authorize scholarship and apprenticeship programs, and for other purposes.

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. This Act may be cited as the 'National Cybersecurity Workforce Development Act of 2024'.

SEC. 2. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. (a) FINDINGS. Congress finds that: (1) The United States faces a critical shortage of qualified cybersecurity professionals, with an estimated 500,000 unfilled cybersecurity positions across the public and private sectors as of 2024. (2) Federal agencies have reported significant difficulty recruiting and retaining cybersecurity talent due to competition with private-sector compensation and lengthy hiring processes. (3) Expanding the cybersecurity workforce pipeline through scholarships, apprenticeships, and community college partnerships is essential to national security. (b) PURPOSE. The purpose of this Act is to establish coordinated Federal programs to recruit, train, and retain cybersecurity professionals to address the growing threat landscape.

SEC. 3. CYBERSECURITY SCHOLARSHIP-FOR-SERVICE PROGRAM EXPANSION. (a) The Director of the National Science Foundation, in coordination with the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall expand the Federal Cyber Scholarship-for-Service program under section 302 of the Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 (15 U.S.C. 7442) to support not fewer than 5,000 scholarship recipients annually by fiscal year 2027. (b) COMMUNITY COLLEGE PARTNERSHIPS. The Director shall establish partnerships with not fewer than 200 community colleges to create two-year cybersecurity certificate and associate degree programs that qualify graduates for entry-level Federal cybersecurity positions.

title: Clean Water and Watershed Restoration Act of 2024
text:
To amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to reauthorize and strengthen programs for the restoration and protection of watersheds and to establish a national watershed resilience initiative, and for other purposes.

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. This Act may be cited as the 'Clean Water and Watershed Restoration Act of 2024'.

SEC. 2. NATIONAL WATERSHED RESILIENCE INITIATIVE. (a) ESTABLISHMENT. Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency shall establish a National Watershed Resilience Initiative (referred to in this section as the 'Initiative') to coordinate Federal, State, tribal, and local efforts to restore impaired watersheds and protect drinking water sources from contamination by per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), agricultural runoff, and other emerging contaminants. (b) WATERSHED RESILIENCE PLANS. Under the Initiative, the Administrator shall provide technical assistance and funding to not fewer than 50 priority watersheds identified under subsection (c) to develop and implement watershed resilience plans that address: (1) point source and nonpoint source pollution reduction; (2) riparian buffer restoration and wetland conservation; (3) stormwater management and green infrastructure deployment; (4) monitoring and early warning systems for contaminants of emerging concern.

SEC. 3. PFAS CONTAMINATION REMEDIATION GRANTS. (a) IN GENERAL. The Administrator shall establish a grant program to assist public water systems and municipalities in remediating per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance contamination. (b) AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. There is authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000,000 for fiscal years 2025 through 2030 to carry out this section, of which not less than 30 percent shall be allocated to disadvantaged communities as defined in section 1452(d) of the Safe Drinking Water Act.
